ygData.subject: Re: Question about Novelty Search
ygData.msgSnippet: Are these issues regarding speciation in novelty search really any different from the very same issues in fitness-based search?  I am still thinking about this

Subject: Re: Question about Novelty Search

Are these issues regarding speciation in novelty search really any
differen=
t from the very same issues in fitness-based search?  I am
still thinking a=
bout this issue, but I am not sure they are really
different.

In NEAT-base=
d novelty search, speciation is still happening as normal.
 One thing speci=
ation does in fitness-based search is protect unique
individuals who may ha=
ve lower fitness based on the idea that they may
take a while to reach thei=
r potential.  By analogy, in novelty search,
the effect is to protect genet=
ically unique individuals who may not be
very novel behaviorally on the cha=
nce that they too may need some time
to discover how to do something novel.=


In other words, speciation means less greedy search.  In some cases,
of c=
ourse, being less greedy means being slower (such as when there is
a single=
 global optimum on a giant hill across the entire search
space).  In partic=
ular, if the most fit (or most novel) individuals
for whatever reason turn =
out to be the best jumping-off points for
even more fit (or more novel) ind=
ividuals, then the time spent on
protected individuals was "wasted."  Yet t=
hat would not be the case in
all domains, so to forego such protection is t=
o take a risk in general.

It could be that in the maze domain a greedier k=
ind of novelty search
would be faster.  But would that be true in other dom=
ains?  An
interesting question is the extent to which novelty search is bet=
ter
served by greediness than fitness-based search.  I am not sure if
there=
 is any basis to believe that it is.

The idea of taking species age into a=
ccount might be interesting, but
the question is still why this considerati=
on would matter more or less
than in fitness-based NEAT?

Overall, the way =
I see speciation interacting with novelty search is
to protect small specie=
s that have unique genotypes even if those do
not translate to novel behavi=
ors in the hope that unique genotypes may
have the potential to turn into u=
nique behaviors if given the chance. 

It is possible that I am misinterpre=
ting the idea that you guys are
developing, so please do clarify my comment=
s if that is the case. 
Novelty search does challenge a lot of common assum=
ptions about search.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" =
<petar_chervenski@...>
wrote:
>
> Yes, I believe so. Perhaps something simi=
lar to the niching mechanism 
> in generational NEAT, boosting younger spec=
ies's fitness and 
> penalizing old species. In Novelty Search this may be =
applied like.. 
> If a species continiously produces novel forms, it is rew=
arded. If a 
> species keeps prodicing the same or close to the same known =

> behaviors, then it can be penalized. 
> 
> Peter
> 
> --- In neat@yahoog=
roups.com, "joel278" <lehman.154@> wrote:
> >
> > Sorry, overlooked your la=
st point about speciation.
> > That is a good point, that perhaps the fitne=
ss of the individuals is
> > not as important as that of the overall specie=
s, since that will
> > determine the amount of offspring a particular speci=
es gets.
> > 
> > So the bias then is to genotypic lines that have produced=
 novelty in
> > the past, which might be a good indicator of novelty in the=

> > Maybe there is a way to reward species in a more principled/ex=
plicit
> > manner? 
> > 
> > Joel

> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "jo=
el278" <lehman.154@> wrote:
> > >
> > > Peter,
> > > 
> > > That is a surpr=
ising result. It seems like never changing the 
> novelty
> > > scores woul=
d create attractors around old behaviors instead of new
> > ones. 
> > > 
>=
 > > For example, imagine an individual that reaches a new area in
> > > be=
havioral space. It is assigned a high novelty score. Several new
> > > indi=
viduals arrive in the same area, and get lower novelty scores 
> (the
> > >=
 first one maintains its high score). What we want is to explore 
> the
> >=
 > individuals on the 'fringe' of this new area, in hopes of finding
> > > =
further areas of novetly. However, with constant novelty scores, 
> the
> >=
 > bias will be to investigate the area in the proximity of the first
> > >=
 individual, even though the ones on the fringe may be more 
> promising.
>=
 > > 
> > > If you consistently get better performance with constant novelt=
y
> > > scores over a variety of maps perhaps it is worth looking into 
> m=
ore.
> > > 
> > > Joel

rvenski"

> > > wrote:

> > > > Hi Joel,
> > >=
 >

> > > > It is int=
eresting to note that when I added the dynamic 
> adjustment of 
> > > > th=
e sparseness/novelty score, the performance was actually 
> worse than

 > > without adjusting the novelty score, i.e. an individual always 
> stay=
s

that this is because it encourages such species 
> that 
> > > > produce mo=
re novel behaviors frequently. But I guess that the

> > > > way is=
 to recompute the novelty scores at regular intervals..

eter

ace around an individual

eneration after each evaluation. In our implementation it is

ed

 the

original individual included.

nd these individuals in behavior

reviously was. As more individuals come

, the novelty of all of them drops, and

> > > > > pressure for =
individuals to do something new in order to be
